author: Cortex XSOAR

automation.description: Deprecated. No available replacement. Run a query through Splunk and format the results as a table.
automation.name: SplunkPySearch

automation.description: Automation to display drilldown search results from Splunk.
automation.name: SplunkShowDrilldown

automation.description: This script is used to convert Splunk comments to a table.
automation.name: SplunkConvertCommentsToTable

automation.description: Automation to display asset objects from Splunk.
automation.name: SplunkShowAsset

automation.description: Automation to display identity objects from Splunk.
automation.name: SplunkShowIdentity

automation.description: Use this script to add a comment with a tag (the "Comment tag to Splunk" defined in the instance configuration) as an entry in Cortex XSOAR, which will then be mirrored as a comment to a Splunk issue. This script should be run within an incident.
automation.name: SplunkAddComment

incidentfield.description: The result of the drilldown search.
incidentfield.name: Notable Drilldown

incidentfield.description: Indicates whether the identity  enrichment was successful.
incidentfield.name: Successful Identity Enrichment

incidentfield.description: The Splunk notable status. Can be one of the following New, In Progress, Pending, Resolved, Closed
incidentfield.name: Notable Status

incidentfield.description: Indicates whether the drilldown enrichment was successful.
incidentfield.name: Successful Drilldown Enrichment

incidentfield.description: Indicates whether the asset enrichment was successful.
incidentfield.name: Successful Asset Enrichment

commands.description: Configures the KV store fields.
commands.name: splunk-kv-store-collection-config

commands.description: Parses the raw part of the event.
commands.name: splunk-parse-raw

commands.description: Searches Splunk for events. For human readable output, the table command is supported in the query argument. For example, `query=" * | table field1 field2 field3"` will generate a table with field1, field2, and field3 as headers.
commands.name: splunk-search

commands.description: Gets the list of notable events that were modified since the last update. This command should be used for debugging purposes, and is available from Cortex XSOAR version 6.1.
commands.name: get-modified-remote-data

commands.description: Searches for specific objects in a store. The search can be a basic key-value pair or a full query.
commands.name: splunk-kv-store-collection-search-entry

commands.description: Returns the status of a job.
commands.name: splunk-job-status

commands.description: Lists all collections for the specified application.
commands.name: splunk-kv-store-collections-list

commands.description: Creates a new search job in Splunk.
commands.name: splunk-job-create

commands.description: Updates existing notable events in Splunk ES.
commands.name: splunk-notable-event-edit

commands.description: Query Splunk to retrieve a list of sample alerts by alert type. Used for mapping fetched incidents through the Get Schema option.
commands.name: get-mapping-fields

commands.description: Returns the results of a previous Splunk search. You can use this command in conjunction with the splunk-job-create command.
commands.name: splunk-results

commands.description: Returns the Splunk's username matching the given Cortex XSOAR's username.
commands.name: splunk-get-username-by-xsoar-user

commands.description: Creates a new KV store table.
commands.name: splunk-kv-store-collection-create

commands.description: Resets the enrichment mechanism of fetched notables.
commands.name: splunk-reset-enriching-fetch-mechanism

commands.description: Adds objects to a KV store utilizing the batch-save API.
commands.name: splunk-kv-store-collection-add-entries

commands.description: Gets data from a notable event. This method does not update the current incident, and should be used for debugging purposes.
commands.name: get-remote-data

commands.description: Deletes the specified KV stores.
commands.name: splunk-kv-store-collection-delete

commands.description: Deletes all data within the specified KV store collection or collections.
commands.name: splunk-kv-store-collection-data-delete

commands.description: Deletes the specified object in store. The search can be a basic key-value pair or a full query.
commands.name: splunk-kv-store-collection-delete-entry

commands.description: Lists all data within a specific KV store collection or collections.
commands.name: splunk-kv-store-collection-data-list

commands.description: Creates the KV store collection transform.
commands.name: splunk-kv-store-collection-create-transform

commands.description: Prints all Splunk index names.
commands.name: splunk-get-indexes

commands.description: Creates a new event in Splunk.
commands.name: splunk-submit-event

commands.description: Sends events to an HTTP Event Collector using the Splunk platform JSON event protocol.
commands.name: splunk-submit-event-hec

playbook.description: This is a generic playbook to be executed for the Splunk Notable Generic incident type. The playbook performs all the common parts of the investigation, including notifying the SOC, enriching the data for indicators and users, calculating the severity, assigning the incident, notifying the SIEM admin for false positives and more.
playbook.name: Splunk Generic

playbook.description: This playbook queries Splunk for indicators such as file hashes, IP addresses, domains, or urls. It outputs detected users, ip addresses, and hostnames related to the indicators.
playbook.name: Splunk Indicator Hunting

name: Splunk
readme:
This content pack runs queries on Splunk servers.

When a query or alert triggers a notable event (incident) in Splunk, the event is stored in an index (table). An XSOAR analyst can fetch the event and its context data all from the XSOAR console. 

We strongly recommend you to use the SplunkPy pre-release version, specifically if you experience any issues regarding fetch logic, including (but not limited to) missing incidents.


## What does this pack do?
Using the SplunkPy integration, you can fetch Splunk notable events. The events contain details such as:
- The name of the alert that was triggered.
- The objects that make up the alert, such as the IP address, hashes, and user names.

Besides fetching notable events, the SplunkPy integration enables you to run drill down searches to retrieve additional data from other tables in Splunk such as:
- Data about the users (department, role, and geographical location)
- Data about the assets (such as hostname, IP address, geographical location, and department)

In addition, the integration enables mirroring between Splunk and Cortex XSOAR.  

**Note:**  
When mirroring or fetching incidents between Splunk to Cortex XSOAR, you need to [map Splunk users to Cortex XSOAR users](https://xsoar.pan.dev/docs/reference/integrations/splunk-py#use-cases).
